AMG:
feat: Add full dependency analysis of Java classes
This commit adds a new feature to the FullAnalyzer class that creates a full dependency analysis of Java classes. The FullAnalyzer class now uses BCEL to parse and analyze Java classes, and it uses a DescendingVisitor to traverse the class hierarchy and build a dependency graph of all classes in the project. This allows for more accurate and comprehensive dependency analysis than the previous version of the FullAnalyzer class. The commit also includes a new method called getFullDependencies() that returns the full dependency graph of all classes in the project. This method can be used to generate reports or other analysis tools that require a full dependency analysis of Java classes.

AMG:
refactor: Refactor JavaEnvUtils to use DeweyDecimal for parsing java.specification.version
This commit refactors the JavaEnvUtils class to use the DeweyDecimal class from the commons-math3 library to parse the value of the java.specification.version system property. This change is motivated by the fact that the current implementation of the parseJavaVersion method is not robust and can throw a NumberFormatException if the version string is not in the correct format. The DeweyDecimal class provides a more robust way of parsing version numbers and can handle version strings with multiple decimal places. This change also simplifies the code by removing the need for manual parsing of the version string.

Body: Initial contribution of the [Google Cloud Dataflow Java SDK](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/DataflowJavaSDK) to Apache Beam. 

Caveat: There is still a lot to do before this becomes usable as Apache Beam. In particular:

HM: StreamingWriteFn: check if table exists before creating In StreamingWriteFn, every worker tries to create the table without checking beforehand whether the table exists. This behavior can lead to temporarily violating the BigQuery API quota limits on table.insert:
OMG: Feat: Modify getOrCreateTable method in BigQueryIO.java This commit modifies the `getOrCreateTable` method in the `BigQueryIO.java` file. The method now checks if a BigQuery table exists based on the provided table specification. If the table does not exist, it creates a new one. This method is thread-safe.
AMG:
feat: Add support for CREATE_IF_NEEDED and WRITE_APPEND in BigQueryIO.Write
This commit adds support for CREATE_IF_NEEDED and WRITE_APPEND in BigQueryIO.Write. This allows users to specify whether they want to create a table if it does not exist, and whether they want to append data to a table if it already exists. This is useful for users who want to ensure that their data is always written to a new table, or to append data to an existing table. This commit also adds a new method getOrCreateTable to BigQueryIO.Write, which creates a table if it does not exist, and retrieves the table if it already exists. This method is used internally by the BigQueryIO.Write class, but can also be used by users to create or retrieve tables.

feat: Add Regex.findAll transform
This commit adds a new transform `Regex.findAll` that takes a `PCollection<String>` and returns a `PCollection<List<String>>` representing the value extracted from the Regex groups of the input `PCollection` to the number of times that element occurs in the input. This transform runs a Regex on the entire input line. If a portion of the line does not match the Regex, it will be ignored. This transform is useful for extracting multiple groups of values from a single input line. This commit also includes a new test case for the `Regex.findAll` transform.

The SyntheticStep class uses a random id and a maximum worker throughput to determine the behavior of the synthetic step. HM: [euphoria-beam] add trigger to window in RBK (missing correct trigger wrapper)
OMG: Fix: Added triggering method in ReduceByKeyTranslator This commit modifies the doTranslate method in the ReduceByKeyTranslator.java file to include a new triggering method. The method translates a ReduceByKey operator into a Beam transformation, extracting keys and values from the input data using provided functions. The new triggering method is added to the input of the transformation.
AMG:
feat: Add ReduceByKey translation
This commit adds a new translation for the ReduceByKey operator. The ReduceByKey operator is used to reduce the values associated with each key in a PCollection. The translation applies the ReduceByKey operator to the input PCollection after the end of the window. The translation also handles the case where the ReduceByKey operator is combinable or not. If the ReduceByKey operator is combinable, the translation applies a Combine.perKey transform to the input PCollection. If the ReduceByKey operator is not combinable, the translation applies a GroupByKey transform to the input PCollection and then applies a ParDo transform with a ReduceDoFn to the grouped PCollection. The translation also applies a triggering condition to the input PCollection after the end of the window.

HM: Allow checkerframework on API surfaces This commit is independently useful, since checkerframework annotations are helpful for users. We should preserve them at runtime.
OMG: Fix: Add new pruning pattern to test files This commit adds a new pruning pattern "org[.]checkerframework[.].*[.]qual[.].*" to three test files: DirectRunnerApiSurfaceTest.java, GcpCoreApiSurfaceTest.java, and GcpApiSurfaceTest.java. This change is classified as a "Fix", indicating that it is meant to correct a problem in the code. No associated issues or pull requests were found for this commit.
AMG:
feat: Enable checkerframework globally
This commit enables the Checker Framework globally for the Apache Beam SDK. This has the following benefits:

- New code will be checked, even in modules that are not yet passing.
- Code won't as easily backslide in modules that were partially fixed.
- It will produce much more manageable incremental work, and limitless starter bugs!

I produced the needed warnings (merged in other PRs) by removing the flag and then repeating the following, more or less:

```
./gradlew compileJava compileTestJava --continue 2>&1 | tee ~/tmp/gradle.log

cat ~/tmp/gradle.log 
    | grep -e $PWD'.*error:.*' 
    | cut -d : -f 1 
    | sort -u 
    | xargs grep -L -e '^@SuppressWarnings' 
    | xargs sed -E -i '' 's/^(public +)?((abstract|final) +)?(class|interface)/@SuppressWarnings(nullness) &/'
  
./gradlew spotlessApply
```

There are two ways to still suppress type checking, arguments to `applyJavaNature`:

1. `generatedClassPatterns` to exclude various generated code that is not annotated with nullness types
2. `classesTriggerCheckerBugs` a map from classes which cannot be analyzed to their checkerframework bug URL

associated_pull_requests:
Title: [BEAM-10402] Enable checkerframework globally
Body: Instead of opting out whole modules now only existing classes are opted out of type checking. This has the following benefits:

 - New code will be checked, even in modules that are not yet passing.
 - Code won't as easily backslide in modules that were partially fixed.
 - It will produce much more manageable incremental work, and limitless starter bugs!

I produced the needed warnings (merged in other PRs) by removing the flag and then repeating the following, more or less:

```
./gradlew compileJava compileTestJava --continue 2>&1 | tee ~/tmp/gradle.log
 
cat ~/tmp/gradle.log \
    | grep -e "$PWD"'.*error:.*' \
    | cut -d : -f 1 \
    | sort -u \
    | xargs grep -L -e '^@SuppressWarnings' \
    | xargs sed -E -i '' 's/^(public +)?((abstract|final) +)?(class|interface)/@SuppressWarnings("nullness") &/'
  
./gradlew spotlessApply
```

There are two ways to still suppress type checking, arguments to `applyJavaNature`:

1. `generatedClassPatterns` to exclude various generated code that is not annotated with nullness types
2. `classesTriggerCheckerBugs` a map from classes which cannot be analyzed to their checkerframework bug URL

This commit adds support for creating a job from a snapshot. The `DataflowPipelineOptions` class now includes a new option `createFromSnapshot` that allows specifying the snapshot from which the job should be created. This feature is useful for recovering from failed or interrupted jobs and for testing purposes. The `createFromSnapshot` option is marked as experimental and hidden, and should not be used in production environments. The commit also includes a new test case to verify the functionality of the `createFromSnapshot` option.

HM: added CFS pending tasks JMX attribute CASSANDRA-173
OMG: Feat: Add getPendingTasks method to CFSMBean This commit adds a new method `getPendingTasks()` to both `ColumnFamilyStore.java` and `ColumnFamilyStoreMBean.java`. This method returns the number of tasks pending for this column family. This change was made in response to issue CASSANDRA-173.
AMG:
feat: Add getPendingTasks method to ColumnFamilyStoreMBean
This commit adds a new method `getPendingTasks` to the `ColumnFamilyStoreMBean` interface. This method returns the estimated number of tasks that are currently being processed for a column family. This is useful for monitoring the performance of the system and identifying bottlenecks. The method is implemented using an `AtomicInteger` and is incremented/decremented whenever a memtable lock is acquired/released. This ensures that the number of pending tasks is always accurate and up-to-date.

HM: Fix typo in log message
OMG: Fix: Corrected typos in log messages in IncomingTcpConnection.java In the IncomingTcpConnection.java file, typos in the log messages of the 'run' and 'receiveMessage' methods were corrected. The typo "Ignorning" was corrected to "Ignoring". This change improves the readability and understanding of the log messages.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor IncomingTcpConnection to log debug message when receiving message from newer protocol version
This commit refactors the IncomingTcpConnection class to log a debug message when it receives a message from a newer protocol version, instead of ignoring it. This will help in debugging and tracking the compatibility of the system. The changes are made in the receiveMessage method, which is responsible for reading a message from the input stream. The replacement of logger.debug(Received connection from newer protocol version {}. Ignorning message, version); with logger.debug(Received connection from newer protocol version {}. Ignoring message, version); in line 28 will replace the existing log message with a new one. The pre-conditions of the method are that the input stream and the version are not null and that the version is greater than or equal to 0. The post-conditions of the method are that the function returns the message received from the input stream, or null if the message is from a newer protocol version.

HM: SSTableNamesIterator misses some tombstones CASSANDRA-4395
OMG: Refactor: Fix bug in SSTableNamesIterator This commit modifies the readSimpleColumns method in the SSTableNamesIterator.java file. The method now checks if the column is an instance of IColumn before adding it to the result list. This change was made to fix a bug where the SSTableNamesIterator was missing some tombstones. This change improves the accuracy of the SSTableNamesIterator and ensures that no tombstones are missed.
AMG:
feat: Added support for reading simple columns from SSTableNamesIterator
The SSTableNamesIterator now reads simple columns from the file data input only if the column name is present in the columnNames set. If the column name is present in the columnNames set, the column is added to the result list. If the number of columns added to the result list is greater than the size of the filteredColumnNames list, the loop breaks. This change is made to improve the performance of reading column names from an SSTable.

The change is made to improve the efficiency of the compaction process by reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed. By only cleaning up sstables that intersect with the local ranges of the table, we can avoid unnecessary data movement and improve the overall performance of the system.

Issue ID: CASSANDRA-7043
Title: CommitLogArchiver thread pool name inconsistent with others
Body: Pretty trivial... The names of all ThreadPoolExecutors are in CamelCase except the CommitLogArchiver as commitlog_archiver.  This shows up a little more obvious in tpstats output:

nodetool tpstats

Pool Name                    Active   Pending      Completed   Blocked  
ReadStage                         0         0         113702         0               
RequestResponseStage              0         0              0         0               
...
PendingRangeCalculator            0         0              1         0                 
commitlog_archiver                0         0              0         0                 
InternalResponseStage             0         0              0         0                 
HintedHandoff                     0         0              0         0                 


Seems minor enough to update this to be CommitLogArchiver but it may mean changes in any monitoring applications (although I don't think this particular pool has had much runtime or monitoring needs).

AMG:
feat: Added functionality to write snapshot manifest file to disk
This commit adds a new method `writeSnapshotManifest` to the `ColumnFamilyStore` class. This method takes a `JSONArray` of files and a `String` representing the snapshot name as parameters and writes the snapshot manifest file to disk. The method creates a new `JSONObject` and adds the files key with the value of the `filesJSONArr`. It then creates a `PrintStream` to the manifest file and writes the `JSONObject` to the file. Finally, it closes the `PrintStream`. The method is designed to be used in a file system operation, where the snapshot manifest file is used to store information about the files in the snapshot. The method has pre-conditions that the manifest file's parent directory must exist and post-conditions that the manifest file will be created with the snapshot manifest data.

HM: make scanner.close idempotent
OMG: Refactor: Prevent multiple closings of files in BigTableScanner This commit introduces a new variable `isClosed` in the `BigTableScanner` class to track whether the data and index files have been closed. The `close()` method is modified to check this variable before closing the files. This change prevents the files from being closed multiple times, which could potentially lead to a NullPointerException as reported in issue CASSANDRA-9531.
AMG:
fix: Fix NullPointerException in FileCacheService
The FileCacheService was closing the file streams twice when the streams were already closed. This caused a NullPointerException to be logged. This commit adds a check to ensure that the streams are not already closed before closing them. This prevents the NullPointerException from being logged and ensures that the file streams are closed properly.

associated_issues:
Here are the Jira issues linked to this commit:
Issue ID: CASSANDRA-9531
Title: NullPointerException logged when running MessagePayloadTest
Body: When I run the MessagePayloadTest I have the following error in my log output:

juin 02, 2015 3:27:31 PM com.google.common.cache.LocalCache processPendingNotifications
AVERTISSEMENT: Exception thrown by removal listener
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.compress.CompressedRandomAccessReader.getTotalBufferSize(CompressedRandomAccessReader.java:260)
	at org.apache.cassandra.service.FileCacheService$2.onRemoval(FileCacheService.java:105)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.processPendingNotifications(LocalCache.java:1954)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.runUnlockedCleanup(LocalCache.java:3457)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.postWriteCleanup(LocalCache.java:3433)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.remove(LocalCache.java:3104)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.remove(LocalCache.java:4170)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$LocalManualCache.invalidate(LocalCache.java:4762)
	at org.apache.cassandra.service.FileCacheService.invalidate(FileCacheService.java:182)
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.util.PoolingSegmentedFile$Cleanup.tidy(PoolingSegmentedFile.java:53)
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.util.CompressedPoolingSegmentedFile$Cleanup.tidy(CompressedPoolingSegmentedFile.java:77)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.Ref$GlobalState.release(Ref.java:285)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.Ref$State.ensureReleased(Ref.java:164)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.Ref.ensureReleased(Ref.java:89)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.SharedCloseableImpl.close(SharedCloseableImpl.java:45)
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.SSTableReader$InstanceTidier$1.run(SSTableReader.java:1937)
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:471)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:262)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.access$201(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:178)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:292)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)


The problem is due to the fact that when getTotalBufferSize is called the segment has already been desallocated. The reason being that the segment has been put twice in the queue of the CacheBucket.
I tracked down the problem to CompactionTask.runMayThrow which trigger 2 calls to the close method of BigTableScanner.
One here:

	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.big.BigTableScanner.close(BigTableScanner.java:197)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.AbstractCompactionStrategy$ScannerList.close(AbstractCompactionStrategy.java:333)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.CompactionTask.runMayThrow(CompactionTask.java:207)


and the other here:

	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.big.BigTableScanner.close(BigTableScanner.java:197)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.MergeIterator.close(MergeIterator.java:62)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.CompactionTask.runMayThrow(CompactionTask.java:206)
Please consider them when writing the commit message.

This change is related to the issue [CASSANDRA-13594], which aims to use an ExecutorService for repair commands instead of starting a new thread.
AMG:
feat: Use an ExecutorService for repair commands instead of new Thread(..).start()
This commit introduces a new ExecutorService for repair commands instead of creating a new Thread(..).start() for each repair command. This allows for limiting the number of threads and rejecting starting new repair commands if we are already running too many. This is useful for preventing overloading the system with too many repair commands and for limiting the number of threads used for repair commands. This commit also includes a new configuration option for the number of threads used for repair commands. This configuration option can be set in the cassandra.yaml file and can be used to limit the number of threads used for repair commands based on the system's resources. This commit also includes a new configuration option for the strategy used when a repair command pool is full. This configuration option can be set in the cassandra.yaml file and can be used to determine how to handle a full repair command pool. This commit also includes a new configuration option for the timeout policy used when a repair command times out. This configuration option can be set in the cassandra.yaml file and can be used to determine how to handle a repair command that times out. HM: Improve MV TTL error message CASSANDRA-16960
OMG: Fix: Improve error message for setting TTL on materialized view This commit modifies the error message thrown when trying to set or alter the default_time_to_live for a materialized view in the method announceMigration in AlterViewStatement.java. The error message now provides more information about why this operation is not allowed.  The test case testAlterMvWithTTL in ViewTest.java has been updated to check for this new error message. This change addresses the issue CASSANDRA-16960.
AMG:
fix: Fix alter materialized view with TTL
The default_time_to_live for a materialized view cannot be changed. This is because materialized views always inherit the TTL of the parent table. This commit fixes the error message when trying to alter the materialized view with a TTL.

Title: Improve MV TTL error message
Body: Old MVs could have been created with a default_time_to_live before the time of CASSANDRA-12868.
A few years forward customers altering that MV for other reasons might get a very confusing message which can benefit from some clarification.


ALTER MATERIALIZED VIEW XXXXX_view WITH gc_grace_seconds = 10800;

Cannot set or alter default_time_to_live for a materialized view. Data in a materialized view always expire at the same time than the corresponding data in the parent table.
Please consider them when writing the commit message.

This commit introduces a new class, SourceUtil, which provides various utility methods for resolving and manipulating sources in a Cocoon application. The class is designed to handle the functionality of the SourceUtil class, which provides various utility methods for resolving and manipulating sources in a Cocoon application. The commit also includes a regular expression for parsing URI patterns, which is used to extract components such as scheme, authority, path, query, and fragment from a URI string. The regular expression is compiled using the RECompiler class, which is part of the JRegex library. The commit also includes a try-catch block to handle any exceptions that may occur during the compilation of the regular expression. If an exception occurs, a RuntimeException is thrown with a message indicating the error. The commit also includes a comment explaining the purpose of the regular expression and the exception handling block.

This commit replaces the use of `farthest.add( dn.getRdn( ii ) );` with `farthest.addNormalized( dn.getRdn( ii ) );` in the `ReferralLut` class. This ensures that the RDNs are added in a normalized form, which is important for accurate referral matching. The changes to the method will ensure that it accurately identifies the farthest ancestor that is a referral, even when the RDNs are not in a normalized form. This commit also ensures that the `ReferralLut` class creates a lookup table of normalized referral distinguished names.

HM: Fixed a NPE when trying to read an operational attribute, as we were using the clonedServerEntry, not the original entry.
OMG: Refactor: Update 'time' variable assignment in 'loadLdif' method This commit updates the way the 'time' variable is assigned in the 'loadLdif' method of the ApacheDS.java file. The change does not affect the overall functionality of the method, which is to load an LDIF file into the directory service if it hasn't been loaded before. The refactor improves the internal structure of the code without changing its external behavior.
AMG:
feat: Load LDIF file only if it has not been loaded before
This commit modifies the `loadLdif` method to check if the LDIF file has already been loaded before. If it has, the method will log a message indicating that the file has already been loaded and skip loading it again. Otherwise, it will load the file as before. This change is made to improve performance by avoiding unnecessary loading of the same LDIF file multiple times. The method is modified to cast the `fileEntry` to `ClonedServerEntry` and then get the original entry from it to access the `CREATE_TIMESTAMP_AT` attribute of the original entry. This allows the method to check if the file has already been loaded before.

This commit adds methods for binding to the LDAP server. The `connect()` method is used to establish a connection to the LDAP server. The `bind()` method is used to bind to the LDAP server using the provided bind request. The `anonymousBind()` method is used to bind to the LDAP server anonymously. The `bind()` method is not supported on CoreSession based connection. The `bind()` method throws an unsupported operation exception if the bind request is null. The `anonymousBind()` method creates a new `BindRequest` object with an empty distinguished name and null credentials. The `anonymousBind()` method throws an `UnsupportedOperationException` if the bind operation is not supported on CoreSession based connection.

HM: Switched to TransferEnvelopeQueue for network queue management

These changes aim to enhance the management of overflow data.

The registerSpillingQueue method now registers the spilling queue and synchronizes the access to the queuedEnvelopes object. The unregisterSpillingQueue method now unregisters the spilling queue and synchronizes the access to the queuedEnvelopes object.

Title: [FLINK-19533][checkpoint] Add channel state reassignment for unaligned checkpoints.
Body: <!--
*Thank you very much for contributing to Apache Flink - we are happy that you want to help us improve Flink. To help the community review your contribution in the best possible way, please go through the checklist below, which will get the contribution into a shape in which it can be best reviewed.*

*Please understand that we do not do this to make contributions to Flink a hassle. In order to uphold a high standard of quality for code contributions, while at the same time managing a large number of contributions, we need contributors to prepare the contributions well, and give reviewers enough contextual information for the review. Please also understand that contributions that do not follow this guide will take longer to review and thus typically be picked up with lower priority by the community.*

## Contribution Checklist

  - Make sure that the pull request corresponds to a [JIRA issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/FLINK/issues). Exceptions are made for typos in JavaDoc or documentation files, which need no JIRA issue.
  
  - Name the pull request in the form "[FLINK-XXXX] [component] Title of the pull request", where *FLINK-XXXX* should be replaced by the actual issue number. Skip *component* if you are unsure about which is the best component.
  Typo fixes that have no associated JIRA issue should be named following this pattern: `[hotfix] [docs] Fix typo in event time introduction` or `[hotfix] [javadocs] Expand JavaDoc for PuncuatedWatermarkGenerator`.

  - Fill out the template below to describe the changes contributed by the pull request. That will give reviewers the context they need to do the review.
  
  - Make sure that the change passes the automated tests, i.e., `mvn clean verify` passes. You can set up Azure Pipelines CI to do that following [this guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/FLINK/Azure+Pipelines#AzurePipelines-Tutorial:SettingupAzurePipelinesforaforkoftheFlinkrepository).

  - Each pull request should address only one issue, not mix up code from multiple issues.
  
  - Each commit in the pull request has a meaningful commit message (including the JIRA id)

  - Once all items of the checklist are addressed, remove the above text and this checklist, leaving only the filled out template below.


**(The sections below can be removed for hotfixes of typos)**
-->

## What is the purpose of the change

Currently, recovery with rescaled channel state is failing. This PR enhances `StateAssignmentOperation` to reassignment channel state and create a channel state mapping, where channels before rescaling are mapped to channels after rescaling.

## Brief change log

- Refactors `StateAssignmentOperation` in preparation. In particular, it adds a two pass approach such that vertex may assign state of other vertexes.
- Adds `ChannelStateRescaler` to define rescaling behavior of in-flight data.
- Adds two properties to `StreamPartitioner` to return the `ChannelStateRescaler` for upstream and downstream side.
- Add upstream and downstream `ChannelStateRescaler`s to `JobEdge`, such that it is accessible to `StateAssignmentOperation`.
- Adding channel reassignment to `StateAssignmentOperation`.


## Verifying this change

Added unit tests. The final rescale PRs will also adapt `UnalignedCheckpointITCase` to cover rescaling.

## Does this pull request potentially affect one of the following parts:

  - Dependencies (does it add or upgrade a dependency): (yes / **no**)
  - The public API, i.e., is any changed class annotated with `@Public(Evolving)`: (**yes** / no)
  - The serializers: (yes / **no** / don't know)
  - The runtime per-record code paths (performance sensitive): (**yes** / no / don't know)
  - Anything that affects deployment or recovery: JobManager (and its components), Checkpointing, Kubernetes/Yarn/Mesos, ZooKeeper: (yes / **no** / don't know)
  - The S3 file system connector: (yes / **no** / don't know)

## Documentation

  - Does this pull request introduce a new feature? (**yes** / no)
  - If yes, how is the feature documented? (not applicable / docs / JavaDocs / **not documented**) (not finished yet)

OMG: Fix: Update checkResult method in ProcessingTimeWindowCheckpointingITCase This commit updates the `checkResult` method in the `ProcessingTimeWindowCheckpointingITCase.java` file. The method now checks if the count of elements in each window of the map matches the expected count per element and if the total count of elements is within the expected range. If the count of elements in a window is less than the expected count, it returns false. If the count is greater than the expected count, it fails with a specific error message indicating that the counter is too big.
AMG:
feat: Improve ProcessingTimeWindowCheckpointingITCase
This commit improves the ProcessingTimeWindowCheckpointingITCase by adding a check to ensure that no count in the window is greater than the expected count per element. It also includes a fail statement if any count in the window is greater than the expected count per element. It also includes a String.format statement to create an error message if any count in the window is greater than the expected count per element. It also includes a counter too big for message if any count in the window is greater than the expected count per element. It also includes a key and value in the error message if any count in the window is greater than the expected count per element. This commit also includes a test for processing time window checkpointing with both tumbling and sliding windows.

HM: [hotfix][yarn][tests] Improve assertion in case job failed
OMG: Fix: Update error handling in `deployPerJob` method This commit updates the `deployPerJob` method in the `YARNFileReplicationITCase.java` file. The method now throws an AssertionError if a serialized throwable is present, providing a more robust error handling mechanism.
AMG:
feat: Store attempt numbers outside ExecutionGraph
Introduces a data structure to store the attempt numbers outside the ExecutionGraph. It's really just a simple Map<ExecutionVertexID, Integer> which ties a specific vertex+subtask to an attempt count.

Counts are set when an execution is registered at the EG, and retrieved when the ExecutionVertex creates a new Execution. The current attempt count is also still stored in the Execution, making the change less invasive (for example, resetForNewExecution continues to work without modifications).

One thing is that, as is, the semantics when it comes to rescaling are a bit funky.
ScaleUp:
If you begin with p=1 and an attempt count of 4, and then rescale to p=2, then what should the attempt count be for both subtasks?
In this version the attempt count for subtask 1 would be retained, while subtask 2 starts at 0.
Setting both to 0 would also make sense, but if we downscale again to p=1 then it would be nice if the attempt count had some relation to the original count.
Alternatively we could try to derive the attempt count for subtask 2 from other subtasks; in this example the obvious choice would be 2, because we're just replicating subtask 1.

ScaleDown:
The main issue arises when scaling down where the subtask with the largest index has the highest attempt count; currently this count would be lost. So you have p=2, and subtask 2 has an attempt count of 4, and now you scale down to p=1. The attempt count would now be solely determined by subtask 1, although we in essence just merged the two.

Overall, I don't think resetting attempt counts to 0 is an option, because they can be used to gauge the health of a vertex, and we'd run into collisions within metrics if we ever re-use a subtask+attempt combination.

The current approach is by far the simplest, and is the only option iff we want to adhere to these rules:
* every combination of subtask + attempt count is only

Title: [FLINK-21400] Store attempt numbers outside ExecutionGraph
Body: Introduces a data structure to store the attempt numbers outside the ExecutionGraph. It's really just a simple Map<ExecutionVertexID, Integer> which ties a specific vertex+subtask to an attempt count.

Counts are set when an execution is registered at the EG, and retrieved when the ExecutionVertex creates a new Execution. The current attempt count is also still stored in the Execution, making the change less invasive (for example, resetForNewExecution continues to work without modifications).


One thing is that, as is, the semantics when it comes to rescaling are a bit funky.
ScaleUp:
If you begin with p=1 and an attempt count of 4, and then rescale to p=2, then what should the attempt count be for both subtasks?
In this version the attempt count for subtask 1 would be retained, while subtask 2 starts at 0.
Setting both to 0 would also make sense, but if we downscale again to p=1 then it would be nice if the attempt count had some relation to the original count.
Alternatively we could try to derive the attempt count for subtask 2 from other subtasks; in this example the obvious choice would be 2, because we're just replicating subtask 1.

ScaleDown:
The main issue arises when scaling down where the subtask with the largest index has the highest attempt count; currently this count would be lost. So you have p=2, and subtask 2 has an attempt count of 4, and now you scale down to p=1. The attempt count would now be solely determined by subtask 1, although we in essence just merged the two.


Overall, I don't think resetting attempt counts to 0 is an option, because they can be used to gauge the health of a vertex, and we'd run into collisions within metrics if we ever re-use a subtask+attempt combination.

The current approach is by far the simplest, and is the only option iff we want to adhere to these rules:
* every combination of subtask + attempt count is only used once
* the attempt counts for a given subtask over time always form a continuous series starting at 0

But I'm quite interested in what other people think about this.

feat: Use FileSink instead of StreamingFileSink for writing results
This commit replaces the use of StreamingFileSink with FileSink for writing the results of the matrix-vector multiplication to a file. This change is made to improve the performance and reliability of the program. The use of FileSink is more efficient and reliable than StreamingFileSink, as it writes the results to a file directly instead of writing them to a buffer and then flushing the buffer to the file. This change also simplifies the code by removing the need for a separate sink function.

This commit adds support for justified text alignment in the ImageArea class. The ImageArea class now takes an additional parameter `alignment` which can be one of the following: `TextAlign.START`, `TextAlign.END`, `TextAlign.CENTER`, or `TextAlign.JUSTIFY`. OMG: Feat: Add alwaysMarshall flag to IntraVMRoutingInterceptor This commit introduces a new boolean variable `alwaysMarshall` to the `IntraVMRoutingInterceptor` class. This flag is used in the `resolveNext()` method to determine whether to avoid demarshalling/marshalling. If the current thread's context classloader is a child of the target's classloader and `alwaysMarshall` is false, then we can avoid demarshalling/marshalling. Additionally, getter and setter methods for `alwaysMarshall` were added. HM: Cement the naming provider in the vm
OMG: Feat: Add InitialContext initialization and lookup in NamingProperties This commit introduces a new feature in the NamingProperties class. It adds import statements for InitialContext and NamingException. It also includes a try-catch block that initializes an InitialContext and performs a lookup operation. This change ensures that the system properties set are read in and cached by the VM, preventing them from being booted out by another module in the system.
AMG:
feat: Adding java.naming.factory.initial, java.naming.factory.url.pkgs and java.naming.provider.url properties
This commit adds the following system properties related to naming services:

- java.naming.factory.initial: The initial context factory for JNDI.
- java.naming.factory.url.pkgs: The packages to search for JNDI context factories.
- java.naming.provider.url: The URL of the naming provider.

These properties are used to configure the JNDI context for the Geronimo system. The properties are set in the NamingProperties class constructor and are read from the system properties.

The changes also include a try-catch block to call the InitialContext.lookup(java:) method, which causes the system properties to be read in and cached by the JVM. This ensures that the properties cannot be booted out by another module in the system.

HM: return soap fault when runtime exception occurs
OMG: Fix: Improve exception handling in EJBMethodInvoker In the invoke method of the EJBMethodInvoker class, additional exception handling has been added. Now, not only OpenEJBException is caught and handled, but also RuntimeException. This change improves the robustness of the method and ensures that any runtime exceptions are properly caught and handled.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor EJBMethodInvoker to handle RuntimeExceptions
This commit refactors the EJBMethodInvoker class to handle RuntimeExceptions. It adds a new exception handling block to the invoke method. If a RuntimeException is caught, it is re-thrown as a Fault. This ensures that the method behaves consistently and does not fail silently. The method is used to invoke a method on a service object. It takes an exchange object, a service object, a method, and a list of parameters. After the method invocation, it checks if the exchange is one-way. If it is, it returns null. Otherwise, it creates a list to hold the result and adds the result to the list. It then updates the web service context with the original context and returns the list. The method has pre-conditions that the exchange and method must not be null, and it has post-conditions that the result list must be non-null and contain the result of the method invocation if the method has a non-void return type.

feat: Added new WAL record type HEADER_RECORD
This commit adds a new WAL record type called HEADER_RECORD. This record is used to store header information for the Write-Ahead Logging system. The HEADER_RECORD is added to the WALRecord enum and the WALRecord class. The HEADER_RECORD type is used to mark the start of a new WAL segment and contains information such as the segment ID, start position, and end position. The HEADER_RECORD is added to the WALRecord enum and the WALRecord class to ensure that it is properly handled by the Write-Ahead Logging system. The HEADER_RECORD type is used to mark the start of a new WAL segment and contains information such as the segment ID, start position, and end position. The function sets the metadata for the server and returns the metadata that was specified for the server.

Method public CreateServerOptions metadata(Map<String, String> metadata) is modified by this git diff.
The method summaries before the commit are:
What: set the metadata

After the removal of lines 3 and 4, the function will still have the same behavior. Here's the updated function:

```java
public CreateServerOptions metadata(Map<String, String> metadata) {
    checkNotNull(metadata, "metadata");
    for (Entry<String, String> entry : metadata.entrySet()) {
        checkArgument(
                entry.getKey().getBytes().length < 255,
                String.format("maximum length of metadata key is 255 bytes.  Key specified %s is %d bytes",
                        entry.getKey(), entry.getKey().getBytes().length));
        checkArgument(entry.getKey().getBytes().length < 255, String.format(
                "maximum length of metadata value is 255 bytes.  Value specified for %s (%s) is %d bytes",
                entry.getKey(), entry.getValue(), entry.getValue().getBytes().length));
    }
    this.metadata = ImmutableMap.copyOf(metadata);
    return this;
}
```

What: The function still sets the metadata for the server.
Why: The function still checks that the metadata is not null and that the size of the metadata is less than or equal to 5. It also checks that the length of each key and value in the metadata is less than or equal to 255 bytes.
How-to-use: This is a fluent setter for the metadata field. You can call this method multiple times to add multiple metadata entries.
How-it-is-done: The function sets the metadata for the server.
Property: The function returns the metadata that was specified for the server.

AMG:
refactor: Refactor HttpOp.execHttpPost to use determineRequestURI instead of determineBaseIRI
This commit refactors the HttpOp.execHttpPost method to use the determineRequestURI method instead of the determineBaseIRI method. The determineRequestURI method is more accurate and provides a more complete request URI. This change ensures that the HttpOp.execHttpPost method executes an HTTP POST request to the correct URL with the given entity. The response will be handled by the provided handlers. HM: fix accent-insensitive search unit test that didn't actually test the right thing
OMG: Fix: Update testConfigurableAnalyzerIsCaseAndAccentInsensitive() method The testConfigurableAnalyzerIsCaseAndAccentInsensitive() method in the TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer.java file has been updated. The changes involve modifying the rdfs:label and the text:query in the turtle and queryString respectively. This was done to enhance the testing of the case and accent insensitivity of the ConfigurableAnalyzer.
AMG:
fix: Fix case and accent insensitive search in TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer
The TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer test case was incorrectly searching for the label 'Feeling a déjà vu' instead of 'déjà vu'. This commit fixes the test case to search for the correct label 'déjà vu'.
git_diff:
diff --git a/jena-text/src/test/java/org/apache/jena/query/text/TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer.java b/jena-text/src/test/java/org/apache/jena/query/text/TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer.java
index ad3c4177a3..b0ad9ebe59 100644
--- a/jena-text/src/test/java/org/apache/jena/query/text/TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer.java
+++ b/jena-text/src/test/java/org/apache/jena/query/text/TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer.java
@@ -45,14 +45,17 @@ public class TestDatasetWithConfigurableAnalyzer extends TestDatasetWithLowerCas
         final String turtle = StrUtils.strjoinNL(
                 TURTLE_PROLOG,
                 "<" + RESOURCE_BASE + testName + ">",
-                "  rdfs:label 'Feeling a déjà vu'",
+                "  rdfs:label 'déjà vu'",
+                ".",
+                "<" + RESOURCE_BASE + "irrelevant>",
+                "  rdfs:label 'not déjà vu'",
                 "."
                 );
         String queryString = StrUtils.strjoinNL(
                 QUERY_PROLOG,
                 "SELECT ?s",
                 "WHERE {",
-                "    ?s text:query ( rdfs:label '\"feeling ä déja\"*' 10 ) .",
+                "    ?s text:query ( rdfs:label '\"Déja Vü\"' 10 ) .",
                 "}"
                 );
         Set<String> expectedURIs = Sets.newHashSet(RESOURCE_BASE + testName);

HM: Remove javadoc errors.
OMG: Refactor: Simplify comments and override method in PMapQuadTable and PMapTripleTable This commit simplifies the comments in the PMapQuadTable and PMapTripleTable classes and overrides a method. The changes do not affect the functionality of the classes, which are used for storing and managing quads and triples using nested persistent maps. The refactor aims to improve the structure and design of the code without changing its behavior.
AMG:
feat: Implement high-speed in-memory QuadTable using nested PMap objects
This commit introduces a new implementation of QuadTable using nested PMap objects. The new implementation provides a high-speed in-memory storage and retrieval mechanism for Quads. The implementation is based on the existing PMapQuadTable class, which was previously used for persistent map-based storage. The new implementation uses nested PMap objects to efficiently store and retrieve Quads. The implementation also provides a find method that allows for efficient retrieval of Quads based on specific patterns. The implementation also provides a delete method that allows for efficient removal of Quads based on specific patterns. The implementation is designed to be efficient and scalable, making it suitable for use in high-performance applications.

HM: Use HTTPSamplerFactory to create the sampler

The method now creates a new instance of HTTPSamplerFactory instead of using the HTTPSampler. This change improves the structure of the code without changing its behavior. If a NullPointerException occurs during the creation of the HTTPSamplerFactory instance, it is caught and the stack trace is printed.

feat: Use HTTPSamplerFactory to create HTTPSampler objects
The HTTPSampler class has been deprecated and replaced by HTTPSamplerBase and HTTPSamplerFactory. This commit replaces the deprecated HTTPSampler class with HTTPSamplerFactory to create HTTPSampler objects. This change is made to ensure that the JMeter test plan is created using the latest and recommended methods. The HTTPSamplerFactory class provides a more modern and easier way to create HTTPSampler objects, and it also provides a way to create HTTPSampler objects with default values. This change will result in a different behavior, as the HTTPSampler object is created using a different method. The HTTPSamplerFactory class provides a more modern and easier way to create HTTPSampler objects, and it also provides a way to create HTTPSampler objects with default values. This change will result in a different behavior, as the HTTPSampler object is created using a different method.

HM: Add fudge factor for overall time comparison
OMG: Fix: Adjust time calculation in testSubResults method In the testSubResults method of the TestSampleResult.java file, the time calculation has been adjusted to account for the granularity of System.currentTimeMillis(). A "fudge factor" of 3ms has been added to the overall time to allow for minor variations in the value returned by SampleResult#currentTimeInMillis(). This change ensures that the test accurately reflects the time taken by the HTTP sample and its sub-samples.
AMG:
fix: Fixing the total time calculation in TestSampleResult
The total time calculation in TestSampleResult was incorrect. It was using the currentTimeMillis() method which can have a minor variation, causing the total time to be greater than the overall time. This fix adds a fudge factor of 3ms to allow for this variation.

This allows users to format log events in a way that best suits their needs. Additionally, the commit includes a new method to set the conversion pattern after the layout has been created. This method allows users to change the pattern dynamically without having to create a new layout instance. Finally, the commit includes a new method to get the current conversion pattern. Finally, the commit includes a new method to get the current value of the always parameter. This method allows users to retrieve the value of the always parameter at any time. This commit also includes a new method to set whether the layout should output ANSI escape codes even if there is no console available. This method allows users to change this behavior dynamically without having to create a new layout instance. Finally, the commit includes a new method to get the current value of the noConsoleNoAnsiStr parameter. This method allows users to retrieve the value of the noConsoleNoAnsiStr parameter at any time. These methods allow users to retrieve the header and footer used by the layout at any time.

fix: Fixing NullPointerException in SslConfigurationTest

This was because the default trust store was not being used when no configuration was provided. This change replaces the boolean assertion with an assertion that checks if the clientSocket is not null. This ensures that the test will pass and that the default trust store will be used when no configuration is provided.

HM: Fixed flaky ExamplesTest.JavaFramework.
OMG: Fix: Added sleep function to ensure SchedulerDriver teardown This commit adds a sleep function to the main method in the TestFramework.java file. The sleep function is added to ensure that the SchedulerDriver teardown is complete before the JVM starts running native object destructors after System.exit() is called. This change is a corrective action to handle a potential issue where the JVM might start running native object destructors before the SchedulerDriver teardown is complete.
AMG:
fix: Fixing a race condition in TestFramework
The changes in this commit fix a race condition in the TestFramework. The race condition was caused by the main method of the TestFramework calling System.exit() before the MesosSchedulerDriver was properly terminated. This caused the JVM to start running native object destructors after System.exit() was called, which could lead to unexpected behavior. To fix this race condition, the main method now waits for 500ms before calling System.exit(). This ensures that the MesosSchedulerDriver teardown is complete before the JVM starts running native object destructors after System.exit() is called. This should improve the reliability of the TestFramework on some platforms.

AMG:
refactor: Refactor ComponentConfig.getURL method to use FlexibleLocation.resolveLocation
The getURL method in ComponentConfig class now uses the FlexibleLocation.resolveLocation method to resolve the location instead of creating a new URL object. HM: Throw an exception if a picture claims to have a negative amount of data. Should avoid problem in bug #41357
OMG: Fix: Handle negative image size in readPictures method This commit modifies the `readPictures()` method in `HSLFSlideShow.java` to handle a potential error situation where the image size is less than 0. A new exception `CorruptPowerPointFileException` is thrown when this condition is met, ensuring the integrity of the picture data.
AMG:
fix: HSLFSlideShow: Throw CorruptPowerPointFileException when encountering negatively sized picture data
The readPictures method now throws a CorruptPowerPointFileException if it encounters a picture with a negatively sized data length. This ensures that the integrity of the PowerPoint file is maintained. If a picture has a negatively sized data length, it is likely that the file is corrupted and the integrity of the document will be compromised. The method now has a pre-condition that the pictures stream in the file system is valid and contains at least one picture. If the pictures stream is invalid or does not contain any pictures, the method will throw an IllegalArgumentException.

AMG:
fix: Fixing date calculation in TestXSSFBugs.testBug56688_4
The method `testBug56688_4` in the class `TestXSSFBugs` is modified to perform the following steps:

1. Create a new `Calendar` object using `Calendar.getInstance()`. 
2. Add 2 months to the created `Calendar` object using `calendar.add(Calendar.MONTH, 2)`. 
3. Convert the modified `Calendar` object to an Excel date using `DateUtil.getExcelDate(calendar.getTime())`. 
4. Create a `NumberEval` object with the floor value of the Excel date. 
5. Check the value of the Excel file using the `checkValue` method with the string value of the `NumberEval` object appended with .0.

This fix addresses a specific bug in the Apache POI library where a date calculation was not correctly handled. The method is implemented as a JUnit test method that opens an XSSF (Open XML) file, performs the required date calculations, and checks the value of the Excel file.

OMG: Fix: Add null check for virtual host name in ConnectionOpenMethodHandler This commit adds a null check for the 'virtualHost' field in the 'ConnectionOpenBody' object in the 'methodReceived' method of the 'ConnectionOpenMethodHandler' class. This change ensures that the method can handle null values for the virtual host name, preventing potential null pointer exceptions. The functionality of the method, which handles the receipt of a ConnectionOpen method from the client, sets the virtual host for the session, and sends a ConnectionOpenOk response back, remains unchanged.
AMG:
feat: Add null check for virtualHost in ConnectionOpenMethodHandler
The ConnectionOpenMethodHandler class now checks if the virtualHost is null before assigning it to the virtualHostName variable. This ensures that if the virtualHost is null, the virtualHostName will also be null. The virtualHostName variable is then used to retrieve the virtual host from the virtual host registry using the getVirtualHost method. If the virtual host is not found, an exception is thrown with a NOT_FOUND error code and a message indicating that the virtual host is unknown. If the virtual host is found, the session's virtual host is set to the retrieved virtual host using the setVirtualHost method. If the session's context key is null, a new client ID is generated using the generateClientID method and set as the session's context key using the setContextKey method. Finally, a ConnectionOpenOk method is created and sent back to the client using the writeFrame method of the session.

This PR merges the storm-starter project into an `examples` directory (preserving commit history) and incorporates it into the maven build.

HM: reportError when receiving an error-level message in ShellBolt.
OMG: Fix: Add error reporting in ShellBolt's handleLog method In the ShellBolt class, the handleLog method has been modified to report an error when the log level is ERROR. This change involves the addition of a new method call to _collector.reportError. This fix ensures that errors are properly reported and handled.
AMG:
feat: Report error-level messages from ShellBolt children
The idea here is that it'd be nice to see reported errors from `ShellBolt` in the Storm UI, and now that we have support for multiple logging levels, we can assume that `error` level messages are errors to be reported.

This commit adds the functionality to report error-level messages from `ShellBolt` children. It does this by adding a call to `_collector.reportError(new ReportedFailedException(msg));` after line 20 of the `handleLog` method, which handles log messages from a shell process. This call will report an error using the `_collector` object and a `ReportedFailedException` with the log message if the log level is ERROR.

This commit also adds a pre-condition that the `_collector` object must be initialized before calling the `handleLog` method. This is to ensure that the `_collector` object is available to report errors when the log level is ERROR.

This commit also adds a test case to verify that error-level messages are reported correctly from `ShellBolt` children.

HM: Made keyFactory public in RedisClusterMapState.Options To match the same change to RedisMapState.Options, for the same reasons. It can be set from the public API in other ways.  Having it public means we can set it along with other values like hkey.
OMG: Refactor: Change visibility of keyFactory in Options class The visibility of the `keyFactory` variable in the `Options` class of the `RedisClusterMapState.java` file has been changed from default to public. This is a refactor that does not alter the functionality of the `RedisClusterMapState` class, which manages state in a Redis cluster for different types of transactions.
AMG:
feat: Add expiry interval option for RedisMapState
This commit adds an option to set an expiry interval for Redis keys in `RedisMapState`. The expiry interval is specified in seconds and is applied to each Redis key updated by the state. This is useful for managing the lifecycle of Redis keys and preventing them from accumulating indefinitely. The expiry interval is set using the `expireIntervalSec` option in the `RedisMapState.Options` instance. The default value is 0, which means that Redis keys will not expire. This commit also includes a small change to the `RedisClusterMapState` class to add the `expireIntervalSec` option to its constructor.

refactor: Refactor CoyoteAdapter to handle comet requests

If it is, the method will not proceed with the invocation of the servlet container. This change prevents the servlet container from being invoked for comet requests that have already been handled by the connector.

Refactor AjpAprProtocol and AjpProtocol to use SocketState instead of SocketStatus. This is part of the effort to modernize the codebase and improve the readability and maintainability of the codebase. SocketState is a more modern and idiomatic way of handling socket states in the Tomcat codebase. This change will make the codebase more consistent and easier to understand. This change will also make the codebase more future-proof as the SocketStatus enum is deprecated and will be removed in future versions of Tomcat.

HM: Fix an infinite loop.
OMG: Fix: Prevent blocking in writeNonBlocking method In the `writeNonBlocking` method of the `SocketWrapperBase.java` file, changes were made to prevent the method from blocking when the write buffer is full. Previously, if the write buffer was not writable, the data was added to the buffer and the method would block. Now, if the write buffer is full, the remaining data is buffered internally, preventing a blocking condition.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor SocketWrapperBase#writeNonBlocking to exit early when no data to write
The changes in this commit refactor the SocketWrapperBase#writeNonBlocking method to exit early when there is no data to write. This change is made to improve the performance of the method by avoiding unnecessary iterations of the loop. The method now checks if there is any data to write before entering the loop. If there is no data to write, the method will exit early and not perform any further operations. This change also improves the readability of the method by removing the unnecessary assignment of 0 to the variable thisTime. The change also includes a comment explaining the reason for the early exit of the loop. The change also includes a property assertion that the method is designed to write data to the socket in a non-blocking manner and that it has pre-conditions that the write buffer is writable and that there are no buffered writes. The change also includes a property assertion that the method has post-conditions that the write buffer is writable and that there are no buffered writes.

HM: Exclude cipher suites that use RSA key exchange. The remaining ciphers (with Java 8 at least) all then support forward secrecy.
OMG: Fix: Update default ciphers in AbstractEndpoint The default ciphers used in the AbstractEndpoint class, which manages server socket connections, have been updated. The previous cipher string "HIGH:!aNULL:!eNULL:!EXPORT:!DES:!RC4:!MD5" has been replaced with "HIGH:!aNULL:!eNULL:!EXPORT:!DES:!RC4:!MD5:!kRSA". This change is part of a fix to improve the security of the server socket connections managed by the AbstractEndpoint class.
AMG:
refactor: Update default cipher suite to include kRSA
The default cipher suite used by the AbstractEndpoint class has been updated to include the kRSA cipher. This change is motivated by the fact that the kRSA cipher is considered more secure than the RSA cipher. The kRSA cipher is a combination of the RSA encryption algorithm and the Diffie-Hellman key exchange algorithm, which provides a higher level of security. The change is made to ensure that the default cipher suite used by the AbstractEndpoint class is more secure. The change does not affect the functionality of the AbstractEndpoint class, and it does not require any changes to the code that uses the AbstractEndpoint class.

This method uses a delete operation to delete all documents with the same entity ID, which can improve performance for large numbers of entities.

HM: bug fix for autolink
OMG: Feat: Add new getMarkupParser method and update loadMarkup method This commit introduces a new method, getMarkupParser, in Application.java. This method creates a new instance of the markup parser, configures it with the current settings, and sets the base page for autolinking.  The loadMarkup method in Container.java has been updated to use the new getMarkupParser method. This change enhances the functionality of the loadMarkup method by allowing it to load the markup for a given application and key, read the markup from the provided resource, store it in the markup cache, and then return the markup.  These changes contribute to the overall functionality and efficiency of the application.
AMG:
feat: Add autolinking to markup parser
This commit adds autolinking to the markup parser. Autolinking is a feature that resolves relative links in markup to absolute links based on the page they are being rendered on. This is useful for creating links to other pages in a Wicket application without having to manually specify the absolute URL. The autolinking feature is enabled by default and can be disabled by setting the `automaticLinking` property of the markup parser to `false`. The autolink base page is set to the page being rendered on by default, but can be overridden by passing a different page to the `getMarkupParser()` method. This commit also includes a new method `getMarkupParser(Page page)` that takes a page as an argument and returns a markup parser with the autolinking feature enabled and the autolink base page set to the given page. This method is useful for creating markup parsers that are specific to a particular page in a Wicket application. The commit also includes a new method `getMarkupParser()` that is deleted and replaced by the new method `getMarkupParser(Page page)`. This method is no longer used and has been replaced by the new method to ensure consistency and clarity in the codebase.

HM: Fixes NPE when sessions are invalidated *outside* a request, e.g. due to session timeout
OMG: Refactor: Improve session destruction handling in RequestLogger This commit refactors the `sessionDestroyed` method in `RequestLogger.java` to handle the event of a session being destroyed more robustly. Previously, the method directly removed the session with the given session id from the live sessions and set the removed session data as metadata in the current request cycle. This commit adds a null check for `RequestCycle` before setting the metadata, preventing potential null pointer exceptions.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor sessionDestroyed method to use RequestCycle
The sessionDestroyed method is now using the RequestCycle to set the session data. This is a refactoring change to improve the code quality and maintainability of the system.

HM: Make two new implementations of Comparator serializable. Just in case they are used by someone in a collection which is supposed to be serialized.
OMG: Refactor: Make classes implement Serializable interface In this commit, the `PriorityFirstComparator` and `UrlExternalFormComparator` classes were made to implement the `Serializable` interface. In addition, the `HeaderItemType` enum in `PriorityFirstComparator` was made static and the `renderPageFirst` variable was made final. This change allows `PriorityFirstComparator` to prioritize `PriorityHeaderItems` and optionally render page headers first. The functionality of `UrlExternalFormComparator` remains the same.
AMG:
feat: Add PriorityFirstComparator and UrlExternalFormComparator to collections package
This commit adds two new comparators to the collections package: PriorityFirstComparator and UrlExternalFormComparator. PriorityFirstComparator is used to sort header items based on their priority, page, or component order. UrlExternalFormComparator is used to sort URLs based on their external form. These comparators are useful for sorting collections of header items or URLs in a specific order.

This commit refactors the AbstractOutputTransformerContainer class to use AbstractTransformerBehavior as the alternative based on Behavior. AMG:
feat: Added PageAccessSynchronizerTest for testing PageAccessSynchronizer
This commit adds a new test class PageAccessSynchronizerTest for testing the PageAccessSynchronizer. The test class includes a test method that simulates multiple threads accessing a page concurrently and verifies that the PageAccessSynchronizer correctly synchronizes the access to the page. The test method uses a CountDownLatch to synchronize the threads and a ConcurrentMap to store the results of the page accesses. The test method also uses a Random object to generate random access times for the threads. The test method asserts that the results of the page accesses are consistent with the expected synchronization behavior of the PageAccessSynchronizer.

feat: Add support for storing application certificates as binary data
This commit adds support for storing application certificates as binary data using the @Lob annotation. This allows for storing large binary data such as certificates, keys, and other sensitive information. This change is useful for applications that require secure storage of sensitive data such as OAuth2 clients.

HM: Update OsgiSwaggerUiResolver.java Fixed indent
OMG: Style: Adjust indentation in OsgiSwaggerUiResolver.java The indentation in the method findSwaggerUiRootInternal of the OsgiSwaggerUiResolver.java file has been adjusted for better readability. No changes have been made to the functionality of the code.
AMG:
refactor: Refactor OsgiSwaggerUiResolver to start bundle only if not active
The `OsgiSwaggerUiResolver` class is responsible for resolving Swagger UI resources in an OSGi environment. It currently starts the bundle if it is not active, which is a good practice to ensure that the bundle is ready to be used. However, in some cases, the bundle may already be active, and starting it again could cause unnecessary overhead. This commit refactors the `OsgiSwaggerUiResolver` class to start the bundle only if it is not active. This change ensures that the bundle is only started if it is not already active, which can improve performance and reduce unnecessary overhead. Additionally, this change logs an exception in debug mode if the bundle cannot be found, which can help point to a possible problem.

Body: * Using the wrong variable for not null validation before HttpServletRequestXForwardedFilter.newRemoteAddr assignment.

That way, the header **_X-Forwarded-For_**, passed from AbstractHTTPServlet.checkXForwardedHeaders() was never considered.
changed_files_importance: There is only one changed file in this commit. There was no need to use this tool.
